Apernu sur les Agaricus de Patagonie et de la Terre de Feu | url = | journal = Bull. Jard. Bot. Belg | volume = 56 | issue = 3/4| pages = 417–446 | doi=10.2307/3668202| jstor = 3668202 }}</ref> * ''[[Agaricus xanthodermulus]]'' <ref name="pmid16396349" /> * ''[[Agaricus xanthodermus]]'' – yellow-staining mushroom * ''[[Agaricus xantholepis]]'' <ref name="Gerault 2005"/> {{Expand list|date=August 2008}}
[[Echigoshirayukidake (Basidiomycetes-X)]] is also thought to be in ''[[Agaricus]]'', either as a subspecies of ''[[Agaricus blazei]]''<ref name=US6120772>{{cite patent |country=US |number=6120772A |status= |title=Oral drugs for treating AIDS patients |pubdate= |gdate=2000-09-19 |fdate=1998-10-08 |pridate= |invent1=Hitoshi Ito |invent2=Toshimitsu Sumiya |assign1= |assign2= |class= |url=}}</ref> or a new species.<ref name="Watanabe_2008">{{Cite journal|doi=10.1248/bpb.31.111 |pmid=18175952 |year=2008 |last1=Watanabe |first1=T |last2=Nakajima |last3=Konishi |title=In vitro and in vivo anti-oxidant activity of hot water extract of basidiomycetes-X, newly identified edible fungus |volume=31 |issue=1 |pages=111–7 |journal=Biological & Pharmaceutical Bulletin |first2=Y |first3=T|url=https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/bpb/31/1/31_1_111/_pdf/-char/en|format=PDF|access-date=3 April 2018}}</ref>

This is a list of '''[[ecoregions]] in [[Nicaragua]]''' as defined by the [[World Wildlife Fund]] and the Freshwater Ecoregions of the World database.
==Terrestrial ecoregions== ===[[Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests]]=== * [[Cayos Miskitos-San Andrés and Providencia moist forests]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Cayos Miskitos-San Andrés and Providencia moist forest|url=http://worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/nt0110|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> * [[Central American Atlantic moist forests]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Central American Atlantic moist forests|url=http://worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/nt0111|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> * [[Central American montane forests]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Central American montane forests|url=http://worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/nt0112|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> *[[Costa Rican seasonal moist forests]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Costa Rican seasonal moist forests |url=http://worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/nt0119|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> *[[Isthmian-Atlantic moist forests]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Isthmian-Atlantic moist forests |url=http://worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/nt0129|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref>
===[[Tropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forests]]=== * [[Central American dry forests]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Central American dry forests|url=http://worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/nt0209|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref>
===[[Tropical and subtropical coniferous forests]]=== * [[Central American pine-oak forests]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Central American pine-oak forests|url=http://worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/nt0303|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> * [[Miskito pine forests]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Miskito pine forests|url=http://worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/nt0306|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref>
===[[Mangroves]]=== * [[Gulf of Fonseca mangroves]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Gulf of Fonseca mangroves |url=http://worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/nt1312 |publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> *[[Mosquitia-Nicaraguan Caribbean Coast mangroves]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Mosquitia-Nicaraguan Caribbean Coast mangroves |url=http://worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/nt1424|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> *[[Southern Dry Pacific Coast mangroves]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Southern Dry Pacific Coast mangroves |url=http://worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/nt1434|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> *[[Rio Negro-Rio San Sun mangroves]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Rio Negro-Rio San Sun mangroves |url=http://worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/nt1431|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref>
===[[Tropical and subtropical coastal rivers]]=== * [[Chiapas - Fonseca]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Chiapas - Fonseca |url=http://www.feow.org/ecoregion_details_new.php?eco=201 |publisher=Freshwater Ecoregions of the World|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> * [[Mosquitia]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Mosquitia |url=http://www.feow.org/ecoregion_details_new.php?eco=203 |publisher=Freshwater Ecoregions of the World|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> * [[Estero Real - Tempisque]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Estero Real - Tempisque |url=http://www.feow.org/ecoregion_details_new.php?eco=204 |publisher=Freshwater Ecoregions of the World|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> * [[San Juan (Nicaragua/Costa Rica)]]<ref>{{cite web|title=San Juan (Nicaragua/Costa Rica) |url=http://www.feow.org/ecoregion_details_new.php?eco=205 |publisher=Freshwater Ecoregions of the World|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref>

[Map by] GEOMAR, University of Seville, Department of Human Geography. |work=Marine ecoregions |url=http://www.marineplan.es/ES/fichas_kml/mapasfichas/ecoregions.jpg |format=jpg |publisher=marineplan.es |accessdate=2013-09-26}}</ref>

page.title: List of people with the longest marriages

revision.text:
This list contains '''marriages which have been reported as setting records for length''', both extant and historical (by order of length). The length of marriage is based on the reported death of either member, or reported divorce, or the most recent report that both members of the couple were still living. {|class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%" |- !No. !Names !Date of marriage !Length of marriage
(at date of last report or death) !Residence
(at date of record or death) !Record !Notes |- |1 |Karam Chand
Kartari Chand |{{dts|format=dmy|1925-12-11}} |{{ayd|1925|12|11|2016|9|27}} |[[Bradford]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom]] |"Thought to be the longest-married couple in the world" (12 December 2014){{cite web|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/main-topics/general-news/89-years-of-marriage-for-bradford-duo-1-7002114|title=89 years of marriage for Bradford duo|last=Pantry|first=Lindsay|date=12 December 2014|publisher=Yorkshire Post|accessdate=13 February 2015}}
"World's oldest married couple" (10 June 2015){{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/news/13324531.Sunshine_smiles_on_Girlington_s_annual_parade/|title=Sunshine smiles on Girlington's annual parade|last=Young|first=Chris|date=10 June 2015|publisher=Bradford Telegraph and Argus|accessdate=20 October 2015}} |{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/news/14033502.Surprise_birthday_party_for_Bradford_couple_aged_110_and_103/|title=Surprise birthday party for Bradford couple aged 110 and 103|last=Young|first=Chris|date=16 November 2015|publisher=Bradford Telegraph and Argus|accessdate=17 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/12/11/worlds-oldest-married-couple-aged-110-and-103-celebrate-their-90th-wedding-anniversary-5558009/|title=World’s oldest married couple aged 110 and 103 celebrate their 90th wedding anniversary|last=Waring|first=Olivia|date=11 December 2015|publisher=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|accessdate=11 December 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://startsatsixty.com.au/blogs/is-this-the-most-memorable-wedding-anniversary-ever|title=Is this the most memorable wedding anniversary ever?|last=Grenning|first=Russell|date=9 February 2016|work=Starts at 60|accessdate=9 February 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160210015033/http://startsatsixty.com.au/blogs/is-this-the-most-memorable-wedding-anniversary-ever|archivedate=10 February 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/news/14775553.World_s_longest_married_man_dies_at_age_of_110/|title=World's longest-married man Karam Chand dies at age of 110|last=Wilde|first=Claire|date=30 September 2016|publisher=Bradford Telegraph and Argus|accessdate=26 October 2016}} |- |2 |K. Philipose Thomas
Sosamma Thomas |{{dts|format=dmy|1918-2-17}} |{{ayd|1918|2|17|2006|2|19}}{{cite web|url=http://kerals.com/news/fulldetail.php?t=1724&sid=68135d7f6a3f22bf0f025fcdc0bcaf78|title=Death separates world's longest married couple|date=21 February 2006|publisher=Kerala News|accessdate=12 November 2010}} |[[Kerala]], [[India]] |"World's longest married couple" (21 February 2006) |{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2005/06/26/stories/2005062603941000.htm|title=The world's longest-married: now a claim from Kerala|last=Jacob|first=George|date=26 June 2005|publisher=[[The Hindu]]|accessdate=12 November 2010}} |- |3 |Herbert Fisher, Sr.
Zelmyra (née George) Fisher |{{dts|format=dmy|1924-5-13}} |{{ayd|1924|5|13|2011|2|27}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newbernsj.com/news/guinness-95304-fisher-world.html|title=Guinness World Record holder dies|last=Book|first=Sue|date=28 February 2011|publisher=[[Sun Journal (New Bern)|Sun Journal]]|accessdate=2 March 2011|deadurl=unfit|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714172220/http://www.newbernsj.com/news/guinness-95304-fisher-world.html|archivedate=14 July 2011}} |[[North Carolina]], [[United States]] |"Longest marriage for a living couple" (2010-2){{cite web|url=http://marriage.about.com/od/celebritymarriages/p/herbertzelmyrafisher.htm|title=Herbert and Zelmyra Fisher Marriage Profile|last=Stritof|first=Sheri|date=14 February 2010|publisher=[[About.com]]|accessdate=12 November 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110114015606/http://marriage.about.com/od/celebritymarriages/p/herbertzelmyrafisher.htm|archivedate=14 January 2011|df=dmy-all}}
"Oldest living couple" (28 February 2011) | |- |4 |Dr. Sir Temulji Bhicaji Nariman
Lady Nariman{{cite web|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/131415486?searchTerm=%22married%20for%2087%20years%22&searchLimits=|title=MARRIED FOR 87 YEARS|page=4|publisher=News (Adelaide, S.A.)|author=[[Australian Associated Press]]|date=2 August 1940|accessdate=14 March 2018}}{{cite book|last=Nariman|first=Sam D.|title=Dr. Sir Temulji Bhicaji Nariman Kt: a short sketch of his life|publisher=Mody's Diamond Print|year=1941}}{{cite book|title=A natural history of love|publisher=[[Random House]]|first=Diane|last=Ackerman|year=1995|location=New York City|page=268|ISBN=978-0-679-76183-9}} |{{dts|1853}} |{{ayd|1853|12|31|1940|8|1}}+ |[[Maharashtra]], India |"World's record for the longest married life" (2 August 1940) | |- |5 |Liu Yung-Yang

revision.text:
'''Lysianassa''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|l|ɪ|ʒ|i|ə|ˈ|n|æ|s|ə}}; [[Ancient Greek]]: Λυσιάνασσαν) is the name of four characters in [[Greek mythology]]:
*Lysianassa, one of the [[Nereids]].<ref>[[Hesiod]]. ''[[Theogony]]'', 240, [http://www.theoi.com/Text/HesiodTheogony.html (Theoi Project)].</ref><ref>[[Pseudo-|Pseudo]]-[[Apollodorus of Athens|Apollodorus]]. ''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Apollod.+1.2.7&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0022 1.2.7]''</ref> *Lysianassa, daughter of [[Epaphus]] and probably of either Memphis<ref>Pseudo-Apollodorus. ''Bibliotheca'', [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Apollod.+2.1.4&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0022 ''2.1.4'']</ref> or Cassiopeia<ref>[[Gaius Julius Hyginus|Hyginus]]. ''[https://topostext.org/work/206#149 Fabulae, 149]''</ref>. She bore [[Poseidon]] a son, [[Busiris (Greek mythology)|Busiris]], King of [[Egypt]] who was killed by [[Heracles]].<ref>Pseudo-Apollodorus. ''Bibliotheca, [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Apollod.+2.5.11&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0022 2.5.11]''</ref> Lysianassa's possible sister, [[Libya (mythology)|Libya]] also bore to Poseidon twin sons [[Agenor]] and [[Belus (Egyptian)|Belus]]. *Lysianassa, daughter of King [[Polybus of Sicyon|Polybus]] of [[Sicyon]]. She married King [[Talaus]] of [[Argos]] and bore him [[Adrastus]] and [[Mecisteus]].<ref>[[Herodotus]], ''History'', 5.67, [http://classics.mit.edu/Herodotus/history.5.v.html (MIT - Classics)]</ref><ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], ''Description of Greece'', 2.6.6</ref> *Lysianassa, daughter of [[Priam]].<ref>Hyginus. [https://topostext.org/work/206#90 ''Fabulae, 90'']</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}{{Greek myth index}} [[Category:Nereids]] [[Category:Trojans]] [[Category:Women in Greek mythology]] [[Category:Mortal parents of demigods in Classical mythology]]

page.title: Nordic Network for Interdisciplinary Environmental Studies

revision.text:
The '''Nordic Network for Interdisciplinary Environmental Studies (NIES)''' is a research network for environmental studies based primarily in the humanities. By organizing regular conferences, symposia and workshops, NIES aims to create opportunities for researchers in the [[Nordic countries]] who address environmental questions to exchange ideas and develop their work in various interdisciplinary contexts. Fields represented by members of the network include [[Ecocriticism]], [[Environmental history]], [[Environmental philosophy]], [[Science and Technology Studies]], [[Art history]], [[Media studies]], [[Ecological economics]], [[Human Geography]], [[Cultural studies]], [[Anthropology]], [[Archeology]], [[Sustainability Studies]], [[Education for Sustainability]] and [[Landscape Studies]].
NIES is responsible for organizing and editing the research series '''''Studies in the Environmental Humanities (SEH)''''' published by [[Rodopi Publishers|Rodopi]].
Formed in 2007, NIES was originally a cooperation among small academic groups in Sweden, Norway and Denmark. Today, it includes more than 100 researchers from all the [[Nordic countries]]. The network actively sponsors a wide range of educational initiatives, research projects and public outreach activities and is a key partner in pan-European and other international initiatives to build capacity and foster theoretical advancement in the Environmental Humanities. Since January 2011, the network's primary anchoring institution is Mid Sweden University in Sundsvall, Sweden. National anchoring institutions include University of Turku, University of Oslo, University of Iceland, Uppsala University and University of Southern Denmark. The network's current phase of operations (2011–2015) is supported by NordForsk.
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{refbegin}} *http://www.miun.se/en/research/major-research-initiatives/research-groups/nies *http://www.rodopi.nl/senj.asp?SerieId=SEH {{refend}}
== External links == *http://www.miun.se/en/research/major-research-initiatives/research-groups/nies

[[File:Plennie Lawrence Wingo and family 1919.jpg|thumb|Plennie Lawrence Wingo with his wife, Idella, and daughter, Vivian, taken around 1919]] '''Plennie Lawrence Wingo''' (January 24, 1895 – October 2, 1993) walked backwards from [[Santa Monica, California]] to [[Istanbul, Turkey]] (about 13,000 km/8,000 miles) from April 15, 1931 to October 24, 1932 at the age of 36. He remains the Guinness record holder for "greatest extent of reverse pedestrianism".
==Biography==
Plennie L. Wingo owned a small diner in [[Abilene, Texas]], but it closed with the onset of the Great Depression and Wingo was out of work like much of America in 1931. At the time, "stunts" were commonplace such as [[flagpole sitting]], or Bill Williams who pushed a peanut up [[Pikes Peak]] with his nose. Wingo overheard some children say everything had been done, there was nothing left to do, to which Wingo spontaneously responded no one had ever walked around the world backwards. The idea stuck with him, and he thought the stunt could be a way to make some money. He bought a pair of reverse-looking mirrored glasses and trained with a local doctor and on April 15, 1931, facing west, set out east.<ref name=montgomery/>
Wingo had little money and depended on the kindness of strangers and the selling of signed postcards for twenty-five cents to anyone who stopped and asked him what he was doing walking backwards (he would return 18 months later with $4 to his name). He was often stopped by police but carried copies of local newspaper articles describing his stunt. In New York City, he agreed to walk around the top ledge of a 12-story building in return for money, but he was robbed by a partner. Wingo eventually found the thief, beat him up, and ended up in jail but the judge let him go on learning of the circumstances. Wingo walked to Boston where he took working passage on a ship to Germany under a cruel chief steward who worked Wingo mercilessly. From there he walked through Germany south to Turkey where he was told by authorities that he had to leave the country for his own safety. A wealthy Italian paid for his return to Santa Monica, California where he then walked backwards to Abilene. He wore-out 13 pairs of shoes on the trip.<ref name=montgomery/>
Although Wingo often made local newspapers on his journey, his fame quickly faded. Years later, he documented his voyage in the book ''Around the World Backwards''. It was published in 1966 with a small publisher that did not sell many copies, but re-released it in 1982 under a new publisher and cover.<ref>Wingo, Plennie L. ''Around the world backwards'' Eakin Press, 1982. {{ISBN|978-0-89015-363-5}}</ref> In July 1976 at the age of 81, he walked across the width of California, selling postcards for a dollar.<ref name=montgomery/> In preparation Wingo managed to "talk his way" onto the ''[[Johnny Carson Show]]'' (July 20, 1976) which paid him $342 for the appearance.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.weeklystandard.com/thomas-vinciguerra/the-man-who-walked-backward-review-the-retropedestrian |title=The Retropedestrian |work=[[The Weekly Standard]] |author=Thomas Vinciguerra |date=September 23, 2018 |accessdate=September 23, 2018}}</ref>
A biography of Wingo was published in 2018 by Ben Montgomery, titled ''The Man Who Walked Backward: An American Dreamer's Search for Meaning in the Great Depression''.<ref name=montgomery>{{cite book |title=The Man Who Walked Backward: An American Dreamer's Search for Meaning in the Great Depression |publisher= Little, Brown Spark |author=Ben Montgomery |year=2018 }}</ref> He remains the Guinness record holder for "greatest extent of reverse pedestrianism".<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sUaHBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT158 |title=Guinness World Records 2015 |publisher=Guinness World Records |author= |year=2015 |page=155 |accessdate=September 23, 2018}}</ref>
He died at home age 98 and is buried in [[Wichita Falls, Texas]].<ref name=montgomery/>
==See also== * [[List of pedestrian circumnavigators]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
'''Population equivalent''' or '''unit per capita loading''', ('''PE'''), in [[Industrial wastewater treatment|waste-water treatment]] is the number expressing the ratio of the sum of the [[Sewage|pollution load]] produced during 24 hours by industrial facilities and services to the individual pollution load in household [[sewage]] produced by one person in the same time.
For practical calculations, it is assumed that one unit equals to 54 grams of [[Biochemical oxygen demand|BOD]] per 24 hours.In Poland BOD5 of 1 person = 60g O2/day ([http://www.stat.gov.pl/gus/definicje_ENG_HTML.htm?id=ANG-309.htm Central Statistical Office, Poland] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514115813/http://www.stat.gov.pl/gus/definicje_ENG_HTML.htm?id=ANG-309.htm |date=2011-05-14 }}) ::PE =\dfrac{BOD\ load\ from\ industry\ \left [\dfrac{kg}{day}\right ]}{0.054\ \left [\dfrac{kg}{inhab \cdot day}\right ]} :::{| class="wikitable" border="1" |+ '''Population equivalents of wastewater from some industries{{cite book | author = Marcos von Sperling |author2=Carlos Augusto de Lemos Chernicharo | title = Biological wastewater treatment in warm climate regions, vol. 1 | year = 2005 | publisher = [[IWA Publishing]] | isbn = 978-1-84339-002-2 | page = 72 }}''' |- ! Type ! Activity ! BOD PE [inhab/(unit/d)] |- | Food | Canning (fruit/vegetables) | 500 |- || | Pea processing | 85-400 |- || | Tomato | 50-185 |- || | Carrot | 160-390 |- || | Potato | 215-545 |- || | Citrus fruit | 55 |- || | Chicken meat | 70-1600 |- || | Beef | 20-600 |- || | Fish | 300-2300 |- || | Sweets/candies | 40-150 |- || | Sugar cane | 50 |- || | Dairy (without cheese) | 20-100 |- || | Dairy (with cheese) | 100-800 |- || | Margarine | 500 |- || | Slaughter house | 10-100 |- || | Yeast production | 21000 |- | Confined animals breeding | Pigs | 35-100 |- || | Dairy cattle (milking room) | 1-2 |- || | Cattle | 65-150 |- || | Horses | 65-150 |- || | Poultry | 15-20 |- | Sugar-alcohol | Alcohol distillation | 4000 |- | Drinks | Brewery | 150-350 |- || | Soft drinks | 50-100 |- || | Wine | 5 |- | Textiles | Cotton | 2800 |- || | Wool | 5600 |- || | Rayon | 550 |- || | Nylon | 800 |- || | Polyester | 3700 |- || | Wool washing | 2000-4500 |- || | Dyeing | 2000-3500 |- || | Textile bleaching | 250-350 |- | Leather and tanneries | Tanning | 1000-3500 |- || | Shoes | 300 |- | Pulp and paper | Pulp | 600 |- || | Paper | 100-300 |- || | Pulp and paper integrated | 1000-10000 |- | Chemical industrial | Paint | 20 |- || | Soap | 1000 |- || | Petroleum refinery | 1 |- || | PVC | 200 |- | Steelworks | Foundry | 12-30 |- || | Lamination | 8-50 |} == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Environmental science]] [[Category:Waste treatment technology]] [[Category:Sewerage]] [[Category:Equivalent units]]

{{undue|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox company |name = Raytheon Company |logo = [[File:Raytheon.svg|200px|center]] | image = Raytheon headquarters.jpg | image_size = 220px | image_caption = Entrance to Raytheon's headquarters complex in [[Waltham, Massachusetts]] |type = [[Public company|Public]] |traded_as = {{Unbulleted list|{{NYSE|RTN}}|[[S&P 100]] component|[[S&P 500]] component}} |foundation = [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], [[Massachusetts]], United States (1922) |founder = [[Vannevar Bush]]
Laurence K. Marshall
Charles G. Smith |location = [[Waltham, Massachusetts|Waltham]], [[Massachusetts]],
United States |area_served = [[World]]wide |key_people = [[Thomas A. Kennedy]]{{cite web |url=http://www.raytheon.com/ourcompany/rtnwcm/groups/public/documents/profile/bio_kennedy.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-01-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104030143/http://www.raytheon.com/ourcompany/rtnwcm/groups/public/documents/profile/bio_kennedy.pdf |archivedate=2015-01-04 |df= }}
{{small|([[Chairman]] and [[CEO]])}} |industry = [[Aerospace manufacturer|Aerospace]] and [[Defense contractor|Defense]] | revenue = {{increase}} US$25.348 billion {{small|(2017)}}{{cite web|url= https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1047122/000104712218000022/rtn-12312017x10k.htm |title=Raytheon Company 2017 Annual Report (Form 10-K) |publisher=[[United States Securities and Exchange Commission]] |website=sec.gov |date=January 2018}} | operating_income = {{nowrap|{{increase}} US$3.318 billion {{small|(2017)}}}} | net_income = {{decrease}} US$2.024 billion {{small|(2017)}} | assets = {{increase}} US$30.860 billion {{small|(2017)}} | equity = {{decrease}} US$9.963 billion {{small|(2017)}} |num_employees = ~64,000 {{small|(2017)}} |website = {{URL|raytheon.com}} }} The '''Raytheon Company''' is a major [[List of United States defense contractors|U.S. defense contractor]] and industrial corporation with core [[manufacturing]] concentrations in [[weapon]]s and military and commercial [[electronics]]. It was previously involved in corporate and special-mission [[aircraft]] until early 2007. Raytheon is the world's largest producer of [[guided missile]]s.[http://www.sazhightechconnect.com/headlines/index.cfm?action=view&articleID=265 Missile maker hopes to diversify, create technology for peacetime] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120211203015/http://www.sazhightechconnect.com/headlines/index.cfm?action=view&articleID=265 |date=2012-02-11 }}. Sazhightechconnect.com. Retrieved on 2012-02-04. Established in 1922, the company [[Incorporation (business)|reincorporated]] in 1928 and adopted its present name in 1959. As of 2017 the company had around 64,000 employees worldwide and annual revenues of approximately [[United States dollar|US$]]25.35 billion.{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/fortune500/raytheon/|title=Raytheon|website=Fortune|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-15}} More than 90% of Raytheon's revenues were obtained from military contracts and, as of 2012, it was the fifth-largest military contractor in the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.defensenews.com/article/20120621/DEFREG02/306210005/Defense-News-Top-100-Revenue-Declines-Just-Beginning-U-S-Budget-Cuts-Loom|title=Defense News Top 100|accessdate=2013-01-01|year=2012|publisher=Defense News Research}} {{As of|2015}}, it is the third largest [[List of United States defense contractors|defense contractor in the United States]] by defense [[revenue]].[http://people.defensenews.com/top-100/ "Top 100 for 2015."] Defense News. 2015. Retrieved on 2016-07-26. In 2003, Raytheon's headquarters moved from [[Lexington, Massachusetts]], to [[Waltham, Massachusetts]].[http://www2.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/02-23-2004/0002114856&EDATE= New Raytheon Headquarters to Open October 27 in Waltham, Mass.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314142252/http://www2.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=%2Fwww%2Fstory%2F02-23-2004%2F0002114856&EDATE= |date=2012-03-14 }} October 22, 2003 Raytheon. The company had previously been headquartered in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], from 1922 to 1928, [[Newton, Massachusetts]], from 1928 to 1941, Waltham from 1941 to 1961 and Lexington from 1961 to 2003. ==History== [[File:Raytheon1934TubeBox.PNG|thumb|right|upright 0.5|An early Raytheon tube box]] [[File:Tomahawk Block IV cruise missile.jpg|thumb|right|A Raytheon [[Tomahawk Block IV]] cruise missile during a U.S. Navy flight test at [[NAWS China Lake]], California (November 10, 2002)]] ===Early years=== In 1922, two former [[Tufts University School of Engineering]] roommates Laurence K. Marshall and [[Vannevar Bush]], along with scientist Charles G. Smith, founded the American Appliance Company in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]].Raytheon Australia. [http://www.raytheon.com.au/Default.aspx?x=12 History.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830113341/http://www.raytheon.com.au/Default.aspx?x=12 |date=2007-08-30 }} ''Raytheon Marketing Material''. Its focus, which was originally on new [[refrigeration]] technology, soon shifted to [[electronics]]. The company's first product was a gaseous ([[helium]]) [[rectifier]] that was based on Charles Smith's earlier [[Astronomy|astronomical]] research of the star [[Zeta Puppis]].Otto J. Scott, The Creative Ordeal, (New York, Atheneum, 1974),16–32 The electron tube was christened with the name ''Raytheon'' ("light of/from the gods"[http://www.raytheon.com/ourcompany/history/early/ Raytheon Company: The Early Days]. Raytheon.com. September 30, 2007. Retrieved on 2012-02-04. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415102900/http://www.raytheon.com/ourcompany/history/early/ |date=April 15, 2009 }}) and was used in a [[battery eliminator]], a type of [[Receiver (radio)|radio-receiver]] [[power supply]] that plugged into the [[power grid]] in place of large [[battery (electricity)|batteries]]. This made it possible to convert household [[alternating current]] to [[direct current]] for radios and thus eliminate the need for expensive, short-lived batteries. In 1925, the company changed its name to Raytheon Manufacturing Company and began marketing its rectifier, under the Raytheon brand name, with commercial success. In 1928 Raytheon merged with Q.R.S. Company, an American manufacturer of electron tubes and switches, to form the successor of the same name, Raytheon Manufacturing Company.{{cn|date=March 2017}} By the 1930s, it had already grown to become one of the world's largest vacuum tube manufacturing companies.{{cn|date=March 2017}} In 1933 it diversified by acquiring Acme-Delta Company, a producer of [[transformer]]s, power equipment, and electronic [[auto parts]].{{cn|date=March 2017}} ===During World War II=== Early in [[World War II]], [[physicist]]s in the [[United Kingdom]] invented the [[magnetron]], a specialized [[microwave]]-generating electron tube that markedly improved the capability of radar to detect enemy aircraft. American companies were then sought by the US government to perfect and [[mass-produce]] the magnetron for ground-based, airborne, and shipborne radar systems, and, with support from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]'s [[Radiation Laboratory]] (recently formed to investigate [[microwave radar]]), Raytheon received a contract to build the devices. Within a few months of being awarded the contract, Raytheon had already begun to mass manufacture [[magnetron]] tubes for use in radar sets and then complete [[radar system]]s. At war's end in 1945 the company was responsible for about 80 percent of all magnetrons manufactured. During the war Raytheon also pioneered the production of shipboard radar systems, particularly for submarine detection. Raytheon ranked 71st among United States corporations in the value of World War II military production contracts.[[Whiz Kids (Department of Defense)|Peck, Merton J.]] & [[Frederic M. Scherer|Scherer, Frederic M.]] ''The Weapons Acquisition Process: An Economic Analysis'' (1962) [[Harvard Business School]] p.619 Raytheon's research on the magnetron tube revealed the potential of microwaves to cook food. In 1945, Raytheon's [[Percy Spencer]] invented the [[microwave oven]] by discovering that the magnetron could rapidly heat food. In 1947, the company demonstrated the Radarange microwave oven for commercial use. ===After World War II=== In 1945, the company expanded its electronics capability through acquisitions that included the Submarine Signal Company (founded in 1901), a leading manufacturer of maritime safety equipment. With its broadened capabilities, Raytheon developed the first [[guidance system]] for a missile that could intercept a flying target. In 1948, Raytheon began to manufacture [[guided missile]]s. In 1950, its [[SAM-N-2 Lark|Lark]] missile became the first such weapon to destroy a target aircraft in flight. Raytheon then received military contracts to develop the air-to-air [[AIM-7 Sparrow|Sparrow]] and ground-to-air [[MIM-23 Hawk|Hawk]] missiles—projects that received impetus from the [[Korean War]]. In later decades, it remained a major producer of missiles, among them the [[Patriot antimissile missile]] and the air-to-air [[Phoenix missile]]. In 1959, Raytheon acquired the marine electronics company Apelco Applied Electronics, which significantly increased its strength in commercial marine navigation and radio gear, as well as less-expensive Japanese suppliers of products such as marine/weather band radios and [[radio direction finder|direction-finding gear]]. In the same year, it changed its name to '''Raytheon Company'''. During the post-war years, Raytheon also made generally low- to medium-powered radio and television [[transmitter]]s and related equipment for the commercial market, but the high-powered market was solidly in the hands of larger, better financed competitors such as [[Continental Electronics]], [[General Electric]] and [[RCA|Radio Corporation of America]]. In the 1950s, Raytheon began manufacturing [[transistor]]s, including the [[CK722]], priced and marketed to hobbyists. In 1961, the British electronics company [[A.C. Cossor]] merged with Raytheon, following its sale by [[Philips]]. The new Company's name was Raytheon Cossor. The Cossor side of the organisation is still current in the Raytheon group {{as of|2010}}. In 1965, it acquired [[Amana Refrigeration]], Inc., a manufacturer of [[refrigerators]] and [[air conditioners]]. Using the Amana brand name and its distribution channels, Raytheon began selling the first countertop household [[microwave oven]] in 1967 and became a dominant manufacturer in the microwave oven business. In 1966, the company entered the educational [[publisher|publishing]] business with the acquisition of [[D.C. Heath and Company]], marketing an influential physics textbook developed by the [[Physical Science Study Committee]]. ===1980s=== In 1980, Raytheon acquired [[Beechcraft|Beech Aircraft Corporation]], a leading manufacturer of general aviation aircraft founded in 1932 by [[Walter H. Beech]]. In 1993 the company expanded its aircraft activities by adding the Hawker line of business jets by acquiring Corporate Jets Inc., the business jet product line of [[British Aerospace]] (now [[BAE Systems]]). These two entities were merged in 1994 to become the Raytheon Aircraft Company. In the first quarter of 2007 Raytheon sold its aircraft operations, which subsequently operated as [[Hawker Beechcraft]], and since 2014 have been units of [[Textron Aviation]]. The product line of Raytheon's aircraft subsidiary included [[business jet]]s such as the [[Hawker 800XP]] and [[Hawker 4000]], the [[Hawker 400|Beechjet 400A]], and the [[Beechcraft Premier|Premier I]]; the popular [[Beechcraft Super King Air|King Air]] series of twin turboprops; and piston-engine aircraft such as the [[Beechcraft Bonanza|Bonanza]]. Its special-mission aircraft included the single-turboprop [[T-6A Texan II]], which the [[United States Air Force]] and [[United States Navy]] had chosen as their primary [[training aircraft]]. ===1990s=== In 1991, during the [[Gulf War|Persian Gulf War]], Raytheon's [[Patriot missile]] received great international exposure, resulting in a substantial increase in sales for the company outside the United States. In an effort to establish leadership in the defense electronics business, Raytheon purchased in quick succession Dallas-based [[E-Systems]] (1995), [[Chrysler Corporation]]'s defense electronics and aircraft-modification businesses, which had previously acquired companies such as Electrospace systems (1996) (portions of these businesses were later sold to [[L-3 Communications]]), and the defense unit of [[Texas Instruments]]—[[Texas Instruments DSEG|Defense Systems & Electronics Group]] (1997). Also in 1997, Raytheon acquired the aerospace and defense business of [[Hughes Aircraft Company]] from [[Hughes Electronics Corporation]]—a subsidiary of [[General Motors]], which included a number of product lines previously purchased by Hughes Electronics including the former [[General Dynamics]] [[missile]] business (Pomona facility), the defense portion of [[Delco Electronics]] (Delco Systems Operations), and [[Magnavox Electronic Systems]]. {{Citation needed|date=February 2008}} Raytheon also divested itself of several nondefense businesses in the 1990s, including [[Amana Refrigeration]] and [[Seismograph Service Ltd]] (sold to [[Schlumberger]]-[[Geco-Prakla]]). On October 12, 1999 Raytheon exited the [[personal rapid transit]] (PRT) business as it terminated its [[PRT 2000]][http://faculty.washington.edu/jbs/itrans/PRT/PRT2000_Concept.html PRT 2000 System Concept], "Design and Commercialization of the PRT 2000 Personal Rapid Transit System" by S. J. Gluck, R. Tauber and B. Schupp. University of Washington Web Server. system due to high-cost of development and lack of interest.[http://faculty.washington.edu/jbs/itrans/samuel2.htm Raytheon PRT Prospects Dim but not Doomed. Peter Samuel.] October, 1999. ===2000s=== In November 2007, Raytheon purchased [[Sarcos]] for an undisclosed sum, seeking to expand into robotics research and production.Jump up ^ Staff (2007-11-14). "Business Briefs". The Lowell Sun (MediaNews Group). In September 2009, Raytheon entered into an agreement to acquire [[BBN Technologies]].[http://news.prnewswire.com/DisplayReleaseContent.aspx?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/09-01-2009/0005086069&EDATE= Raytheon Announces Agreement to Purchase BBN Technologies] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511112039/http://news.prnewswire.com/DisplayReleaseContent.aspx?ACCT=104&STORY=%2Fwww%2Fstory%2F09-01-2009%2F0005086069&EDATE= |date=2012-05-11 }} WALTHAM, Mass., September 1, 2009. PRNewswire. The acquisition was completed on October 29, 2009.[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/raytheon-completes-acquisition-of-bbn-technologies-66099457.html Raytheon Completes Acquisition of BBN Technologies] MCKINNEY, Texas, October 26, 2009. PRNewswire. In December 2010, [[Applied Signal Technology]] agreed to be acquired by Raytheon for $490 million.[http://www.raytheon.com/capabilities/global_isr/ast/]. ===2010s=== In October 2014, Raytheon beat rivals [[Lockheed Martin]] and [[Northrop Grumman]] for a contract to build 3DELRR, a next-generation long-range radar system, for the [[United States Air Force|US Air Force]] worth an estimated $1 billion.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/06/us-raytheon-radar-idUSKCN0HV23Z20141006 Raytheon wins deal for next-generation U.S. Air Force radar]. [[Reuters]], 7 October 2014 This contract award was immediately protested by Raytheon's competitors, [[Lockheed Martin]] and [[Northrop Grumman]]. After re-evaluating the bids following these protests,{{cite web|url=http://www.defensenews.com/story/defense/air-space/isr/2015/01/22/usaf-3delrr-reevaluate/22138939/|title=US Air Force to Reevaluate 3DELRR Award|first=Aaron|last=Mehta|date=22 January 2015|publisher=|accessdate=7 August 2017}} the [[US Air Force]] decided to delay awarding the 3DELRR EMD contract until 2017, and was to issue an amended solicitation at the end of July 2016.[http://www.janes.com/article/62323/usaf-delays-awarding-3delrr-emd-contract-until-2017 USAF delays awarding 3DELRR EMD contract until 2017]. [[Janes]], 15 July 2016 In May 2015, Raytheon acquired cybersecurity firm Websense, Inc. from Vista Equity Partners for $1.9 billion{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-websense-m-a-raytheon-idUSKBN0NB13S20150420|title=Raytheon to buy cybersecurity firm Websense in $1.9 billion deal|last=Jaisinghani|first=Sagarika|date=2015-04-25|work=[[Reuters]]|access-date=2018-10-30|language=en-US}} and combined it with RCP, formerly part of its IIS segment to form Raytheon|Websense.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/washington/blog/fedbiz_daily/2016/01/raytheon-websense-joint-cyber-venture-changes-name.html|title=Raytheon-Websense joint cyber venture changes name to Forcepoint|last=Bach|first=James|date=2016-01-14|website=[[Washington Business Journal]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-31}} In October 2015, Raytheon|Websense acquired Foreground Security, a provider of security operations centers, managed security service solutions and cybersecurity professional services,{{Cite of Foreground Security|last=|first=|date=2015-10-05|website=[[PR Newswire]]|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-31}} for $62 million.{{Cite web|url=http://www.transactionview.com/deal-news/raytheon-paid-62m-for-foreground-security|title=Raytheon Paid $62M for Foreground Security|last=|first=|date=|website=TransactionView|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-31}} In Januar 2016, Raytheon|Websense acquired the firewall provider Stonesoft from [[Intel]] Security for an undisclosed amount and renamed itself to Forcepoint.{{Cite news|url=https://siliconangle.com/2016/01/14/raytheon-websense-acquires-stonesoft-from-intel-security-renames-combined-company-forcepoint/|title=Raytheon{{!}}Websense acquires Stonesoft from Intel Security, renames combined company Forcepoint|last=Riley|first=Duncan|date=2016-01-14|work=SiliconANGLE|access-date=2018-10-31|language=en-US}} In July 2016, [[Poland|Poland's]] Defence Minister [[Antoni Macierewicz]] planned to sign a letter of intent with Raytheon for a $5.6 billion deal to upgrade its Patriot missile-defence shield.{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/business/21702207-weapons-makers-reckon-missiles-will-be-their-next-big-hit-rocketing-around-world|title=Rocketing around the world|newspaper=The Economist|issn=0013-0613|access-date=2016-07-23}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.spacedaily.com/reports/Poland_moves_towards_multi-billion-euro_Patriot_missile_deal_999.html|title=Poland moves towards multi-billion-euro Patriot missile deal|access-date=2016-07-23}} In 2017, [[2017 United States–Saudi Arabia arms deal|Saudi Arabia signed business deals]] worth billions of dollars with multiple American companies, including Raytheon."[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-raytheon-saudi-munitions/saudi-arabia-agrees-to-buy-7-billion-in-precision-munitions-from-u-s-firms-sources-idUSKBN1DM2XC Reuters. November 23, 2017."[https://www.nasdaq.com/article/raytheon-arm-wins-302m-deal-to-boost-saudi-arabias-defense-cm890838 Raytheon Arm Wins $302M Deal to Boost Saudi Arabia's Defense]". Nasdaq.com. December 13, 2017. == Finances == For the fiscal year 2017, Raytheon reported earnings of US$2.024 billion, with an annual revenue of US$25.348 billion, an increase of 5.1% over the previous fiscal cycle. Raytheon's shares traded at over $164 per share, and its market capitalization was valued at over US$51.7 billion in November 2018.{{Cite web|url=http://investor.raytheon.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=84193&p=irol-reportsannual|title=Raytheon: Investors: Annual Reports|website=investor.raytheon.com|access-date=2018-11-07}} {| class="wikitable float-left" style="text-align: right;" !Year !Revenue
